What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I developed a cultural understanding of various Spanish speaking countries, and I learned new grammar tenses for conjugating. There was a lot of insight learned with regards to Spanish writers and some of their famous works.
It became apparent that I have a learning disability.  I discovered that no matter how much time and energy and practice I put into trying to learn a language at this university, I will not succeed.
I became much better at speaking Spanish within the classroom setting and in general. I also somewhat got over my fear of speaking Spanish in front of an entire class, which was huge for me.
Spanish speaking, writing, listening
I learned how to speak better in Spanish.
I improved at Spanish greatly
This course gave me an introduction to Spanish language and culture.
I learned how to better understand Spanish when spoken. I learned a lot of new grammar and vocabulary. I read books in Spanish.

Language placement can always be tricky because not every single person in the class is going to be at the same level, but if it were possible to group together the students going through the same struggles of learning another language, it would make the class environment more inviting and not as scary.
The structure of the course was challenging but useful for pushing one's language abilities.
We covered material insanely fast, even my peers who were doing well in the course struggled with the accelerated pace.
Very detailed, could have less skits and more review of grammar and key principles.

I think the course should be graded more based on how far an individual has come with speaking, grammar, etc., not whether or not someone test takes well in general, which I feel like is how the course is tested on now. All of our in-class speaking assignments/exercises should mean more than they do.
There could definitely be more speaking in SPAN 120 as well as more time to master the complicated verb tenses.

strengths: organization
weaknesses: a lot of work
Strength: forced to get very good at spanish. Weakness: hard class.

I think that the small size of the classroom and the standardized course schedule made this class helpful for all students. There were a variety of assignment types -- speaking, listening, reading comprehension, supersite, etc. -- that really helped me learn all aspects of the language.

The strengths were that the material, like the vocab, was very practical and good to know. The weakness was that for the books and small stories we read I felt like they were far above our level and so understanding them was very hard.
I would recommend this course to another student if they really want to learn Spanish. It is a huge step up from the L1 class, but it really solidifies a foundation for the language.
Yes, L2 is challenging but you can learn a lot.
Yes, but only one who is confident in their ability to learn a language.
It is a lot of work but valuable skill to have

I would recommend this course to another student because professor Juliana really cares about her students and she wanted the best for everyone this semester. Having a professor who cares so much makes learning the material easier, even though it may not seem like it at the time.
Yes, good to know language
Yes because I do believe you can improve you language skills.
Absolutely: you will improve your Spanish tremendously
I would if they want to learn more Spanish or if they have to take it because of the language requirement.
